properties.name: Webex Teams Room Name
properties.description: The name of the Webex Teams room to post messages to. If using a bot, make sure to invite your bot to the room before attempting to send messages. If you don't want to use Webex, leave this blank

properties.name: Webex Teams Access Token
properties.description: The access token to use to authenticate to the Webex Teams API. Information about using a bot, which is what we recommend, can be found here: https://developer.webex.com/docs/bots

This workflow consumes the Talos Intelligence Blog RSS feed and converts individual blog posts into Cisco Threat Response casebooks if they contain suspicious observables. These casebooks can then be investigated with one click in Cisco Threat Response.

Target: HTTP endpoint called "Talos Intelligence Blow" for "feeds.feedburner.com" with a path of "/feedburner/Talos"

Steps:
[] Get the RSS feed XML
[] If the Etag is the same or there aren’t any recent updates, end the workflow
[] Get the updated Etag and Last-Modified headers
[] Convert the feed XML into JSON and parse out each post’s information
[] For each blog post:
[]> Check if the post has been updated since the last run of the workflow, if not, skip it
[]> Run a sub-workflow to parse this single blog post
[] Update the global variables with the new Etag and Last-Modified date

More information: https://cs.co/SXO_docs
If you have information stored in global variables, you can enable this group and use the set variables it contains to update your local variables with the global variable values

properties.name: Threat Response Environment URL
properties.description: Placeholder for the URL of the Threat Response environment being used. You don't need to provide this, it will be fetched automatically

This workflow takes a Talos blog post, conducts an investigation into it using Cisco Threat Response, and then puts the results in a casebook. If a Webex Teams room name and bot token are provided, a message with the investigation's results will be sent.

Target Group: Default TargetGroup

Targets Used: CTR_For_Access_Token, CTR_API, Private_CTIA_Target, Webex Teams

Steps:
[] Fetch the blog post content and strip out any HTML
[] Request a CTR access token and inspect the blog post content for observables
[] Loop through each observable and get its CTR disposition
[] For observables that weren't clean, conduct CTR enrichment to get sightings
[] For modules with sightings, build the text to post to Webex
[] Create the CTR casebook and, if a teams room is provided, post a message to Webex

More information: https://cs.co/SXO_docs
properties.display_name: 0001 - Talos - Blog Post to CTR Casebook

properties.script:
import sys,re,requests

# Get the blog post URL from the script input
blogUrl = sys.argv[1]

# Request the content of the blog post
blogRequest = requests.get(blogUrl, headers={ 'User-Agent': 'Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/41.0.2228.0 Safari/537.3' })

# Make sure the request was successful
if not blogRequest.status_code == 200:
    sys.exit("Unable to fetch blog content. HTTP code " + blogRequest.status_code)

# Extract the HTML of the blog post
blogHtml = blogRequest.text

# Default the blog post to being unavailable in case we can't find it
postTitle = "Post Title Unavailable"

# Attempt to extract the blog post title from the HTML
titleMatches = re.search(r'<title>([^<]+)<\/title>', blogHtml, re.MULTILINE)
if titleMatches:
    # We found a <title> tag, so use that as the title
    postTitle = titleMatches.group(1)
    postTitle = postTitle[(postTitle.find(":") + 2):]
    postTitle = postTitle.replace("\"", "'")

# Strip <script /> tags
blogHtml = re.sub(r'<script\b[^<]*(?:(?!<\/script>)<[^<]*)*<\/script>', '', str(blogHtml), flags=re.DOTALL)

# Strip <style /> tags
blogHtml = re.sub(r'<style\b[^<]*(?:(?!<\/style>)<[^<]*)*<\/style>', '', blogHtml, flags=re.DOTALL)

# Strip other HTML
blogHtml = re.sub(r'<[^<]+?>', '', blogHtml, flags=re.DOTALL)

# Replace new lines with a space
blogHtml = blogHtml.replace("\n", " ")

properties.script:
import sys,json

# Parse the existing list of observables
existing = json.loads(sys.argv[1])

# Get the new observable information
newType = sys.argv[2]
newValue = sys.argv[3]

# Append the new observable to the list
existing.append( { "type": newType, "value": newValue } )

# Build the new JSON
newJson = json.dumps(existing)

properties.script:
import sys,json

# Get the name of the module being investigated
moduleName = sys.argv[1]

# Parse the existing list of sightings and targets
existingSightings = json.loads(sys.argv[3])
existingTargets = json.loads(sys.argv[4])

# Parse the new sightings
newSightings = json.loads(sys.argv[2])

# Loop through each sighting
for sighting in newSightings:
	sighting["module_name"] = moduleName
	
	# Append this sighting to the master list
	existingSightings.append(sighting)
	
	# Check if this sighting has any targets
	if "targets" in sighting.keys() and len(sighting["targets"]) > 0:
		# Loop through each target
		for target in sighting["targets"]:
			# Check if this target is an endpoint
			if target["type"] == "endpoint":
				# Loop through each observable
				for observable in target["observables"]:
					if observable["type"] == "amp_computer_guid" and not observable in existingTargets:
						existingTargets.append(observable)

# Build the new JSON
newSightings = json.dumps(existingSightings)
newTargets = json.dumps(existingTargets)

actions.title: Convert sighting data to usable text for messaging

properties.display_name: Convert sighting data to usable text for messaging
properties.script:
import sys,json

# Get and parse the sighting data
sightings = json.loads(sys.argv[1])

# Placeholders for output
sightingCounts = {}
moduleNames = []
targets = []

# Loop through each sighting
for sighting in sightings:
	# If there aren't any targets, initialize that array index to an empty list
	if not "targets" in sighting:
		sighting["targets"] = []
		
	# Loop through each target
	targetCount = 0
	for target in sighting["targets"]:
		# Remove the observed time (so two of the same target aren't considered different)
		del target["observed_time"]
		
		# Add this target to our master list if it's not already in the list (and count it)
		if not target in targets:
			targetCount += 1
			targets.append(target)
	
	# Is this module already in our count array?
	if sighting["module_name"] in sightingCounts.keys():
		# Yes, so increment the counts
		sightingCounts[sighting["module_name"]]["count"] += 1
		sightingCounts[sighting["module_name"]]["targets"] += targetCount
	else:
		# No, so add it and its counts
		sightingCounts[sighting["module_name"]] = {
			"count": 1,
			"targets": targetCount
		}
		moduleNames.append(sighting["module_name"])

# Placeholders for output
markdownSummary = ""
markdownTruncated = False

# Were there any sightings to begin with?
if len(sightings) == 0:
	markdownSummary = "* No sightings or targets were found"
else:
	# Loop through the sighting counts
	for module in moduleNames:
		# Make sure the markdown summary (for Threat Response and Webex) isn't already too long
		if len(markdownSummary.encode("utf-8")) > 4000 and not markdownTruncated:
			# It's getting too long, so add a message indicating that the text was truncated
			markdownSummary = markdownSummary + "\n\n Additional information was available but truncated due to message length"
			markdownTruncated = True
		elif not markdownTruncated:
			# The message isn't too long, so append this module
			markdownSummary = markdownSummary + ("\n" if len(markdownSummary) > 0 else "") + "* Module **" + module + "** returned **" + str(sightingCounts[module]["count"]) + " sightings** with a total of **" + str(sightingCounts[module]["targets"]) + " targets**"
